</head>

<body bgcolor=3D"#FFFF99" lang=3DEN-US link=3Dblue vlink=3Dpurple style=3D'=
tab-interval:
.5in'>

<div class=3DSection1>

<p class=3DMsoTitle><span style=3D'font-size:16.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:10.0=
pt;
text-transform:uppercase'>Chapter 1.<span style=3D'mso-spacerun:yes'>&nbsp;
</span>Introduction<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal style=3D'text-align:justify;mso-pagination:widow-orpha=
n'><span
style=3D'font-size:11.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:10.0pt;font-family:Arial;mso-b=
idi-font-family:
"Times New Roman"'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></span></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal style=3D'text-align:justify;mso-pagination:widow-orpha=
n'><span

place
w:st=3D"on"><st1:City w:st=3D"on">Northfield</st1:City></st1:place> Municip=

<p class=3DMsoNormal style=3D'text-align:justify'><span style=3D'font-size:=

<p class=3DMsoNormal style=3D'text-align:justify'><span style=3D'font-size:=
11.0pt;
mso-bidi-font-size:10.0pt;font-family:Arial;mso-bidi-font-family:"Times New=
 Roman"'>The
Northfield Plan is a comprehensive long-range guide to the future of both t=
he
Town and <st1:place w:st=3D"on"><st1:PlaceType w:st=3D"on">Village</st1:Pla=
ceType>
 of <st1:PlaceName w:st=3D"on">Northfield</st1:PlaceName></st1:place>.<span
style=3D'mso-spacerun:yes'>&nbsp; </span>This plan builds upon &#8211; and
expands &#8211; the previous municipal plan adopted in 2000.<span
style=3D'mso-spacerun:yes'>&nbsp; </span>The plan is intended to:<o:p></o:p=
></span></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal style=3D'text-align:justify'><span style=3D'font-size:=
11.0pt;
mso-bidi-font-size:10.0pt;font-family:Arial;mso-bidi-font-family:"Times New=

significant trends that have shaped <st1:City w:st=3D"on"><st1:place w:st=

rich and varied history;<o:p></o:p></span></p>

current conditions regarding a variety of topics, including housing,
transportation, the local economy, community facilities and services, and l=
and
use;<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=3DLevel1 style=3D'text-align:justify;mso-pagination:widow-orphan;

the extent practical, the trends that will affect change in the future; and=
 <o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=3DLevel1 style=3D'text-align:justify;mso-pagination:widow-orphan;

goals, policies, and implementation strategies for addressing community cha=
nge
in a way that will benefit current and future generations of <st1:City w:st=

 w:st=3D"on">Northfield</st1:place></st1:City> residents.<o:p></o:p></span>=

<h1 style=3D'text-align:justify'><i style=3D'mso-bidi-font-style:normal'><s=
pan
style=3D'font-size:14.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:10.0pt'>1.2 <span style=3D'mso=
-tab-count:
1'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; </span>Consistency with <st1:State w:st=3D"on"><st1:p=
lace
 w:st=3D"on">Vermont</st1:place></st1:State> Statute<o:p></o:p></span></i><=
/h1>

<p class=3DMsoNormal style=3D'text-align:justify;mso-pagination:widow-orpha=
n;
tab-stops:-1.0in -.5in 0in'><span style=3D'font-size:11.0pt;mso-bidi-font-s=
ize:
10.0pt;font-family:Arial;mso-bidi-font-family:"Times New Roman"'><o:p>&nbsp=
;</o:p></span></p>

<p class=3DLevel1 style=3D'margin-left:0in;text-align:justify;text-indent:0=
in;
mso-pagination:widow-orphan;mso-outline-level:body-text;mso-list:none;
tab-stops:-1.0in -.5in 0in'><span style=3D'font-size:11.0pt;mso-bidi-font-s=
ize:
10.0pt;font-family:Arial;mso-bidi-font-family:"Times New Roman"'>The Northf=
ield
Plan was prepared by the Northfield Planning Commission under the authority=
 of
24 VSA, Chapter 117,<i style=3D'mso-bidi-font-style:normal'> </i>The Vermont
Municipal and Regional Planning Act (the &#8220;Act&#8221;).<span
style=3D'mso-spacerun:yes'>&nbsp; </span>While towns are not required to ad=
opt a
plan, those that do must include specific elements required in the Act
('4382).<span style=3D'mso-spacerun:yes'>&nbsp; </span>This plan includes a=
ll
required elements.<span style=3D'mso-spacerun:yes'>&nbsp; </span>This plan =
also
addresses the twelve general state planning goals also listed in the Act
('4302).<span style=3D'mso-spacerun:yes'>&nbsp; </span>Although the plan is
consistent with these goals, the background information, goals, and policies
presented throughout the document were carefully prepared to meet the uniqu=
e conditions
and needs of the Town of <st1:place w:st=3D"on"><st1:City w:st=3D"on">North=
field</st1:City></st1:place>.<b
style=3D'mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'><i style=3D'mso-bidi-font-style:norma=
l'><o:p></o:p></i></b></span></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal style=3D'text-align:justify;mso-pagination:widow-orpha=
n;
tab-stops:-1.0in -.5in 0in'><b style=3D'mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'><i
style=3D'mso-bidi-font-style:normal'><span style=3D'font-size:11.0pt;mso-bi=
di-font-size:
10.0pt;font-family:Arial;mso-bidi-font-family:"Times New Roman"'><o:p>&nbsp=
;</o:p></span></i></b></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal style=3D'text-align:justify;mso-pagination:widow-orpha=
n;
tab-stops:-1.0in -.5in'><b style=3D'mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'><i
style=3D'mso-bidi-font-style:normal'><span style=3D'font-size:14.0pt;mso-bi=
di-font-size:
10.0pt;font-family:Arial;mso-bidi-font-family:"Times New Roman"'>1.3<span
style=3D'mso-tab-count:1'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; </span>Regional Coordina=
tion<o:p></o:p></span></i></b></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal style=3D'text-align:justify;mso-pagination:widow-orpha=
n;
tab-stops:-1.0in -.5in 0in'><span style=3D'font-size:11.0pt;mso-bidi-font-s=
ize:
10.0pt;font-family:Arial;mso-bidi-font-family:"Times New Roman"'><o:p>&nbsp=
;</o:p></span></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal style=3D'text-align:justify;mso-pagination:widow-orpha=
n;
tab-stops:-1.0in -.5in 0in'><span style=3D'font-size:11.0pt;mso-bidi-font-s=
ize:
10.0pt;font-family:Arial;mso-bidi-font-family:"Times New Roman"'>Due to its
geography, it makes sense for <st1:City w:st=3D"on">Northfield</st1:City> t=
o work
with adjacent communities to better serve its citizens &#8211; especially
Roxbury and <st1:State w:st=3D"on">Berlin</st1:State> and those located alo=
ng the
Route 12 corridor in the <st1:place w:st=3D"on"><st1:PlaceName w:st=3D"on">=
Dog</st1:PlaceName>
 <st1:PlaceType w:st=3D"on">River</st1:PlaceType> <st1:PlaceType w:st=3D"on=
">Valley</st1:PlaceType></st1:place>.<span
style=3D'mso-spacerun:yes'>&nbsp; </span><st1:City w:st=3D"on"><st1:place w=
:st=3D"on">Northfield</st1:place></st1:City>
cooperates with neighboring communities to provide education, emergency
services and services for families, youth, and seniors.<span
style=3D'mso-spacerun:yes'>&nbsp; </span>That day-to-day cooperation is less
common &#8211; and less practical &#8211; with neighboring Waitsfield and
Warren, which are separated by the <st1:PlaceName w:st=3D"on">Northfield</s=
t1:PlaceName>
<st1:PlaceType w:st=3D"on">Range</st1:PlaceType> to the west, and Williamst=
own
which is separated by <st1:place w:st=3D"on"><st1:PlaceName w:st=3D"on">Pai=
ne</st1:PlaceName>
 <st1:PlaceType w:st=3D"on">Mountain</st1:PlaceType></st1:place> and the I-=
89
corridor to the east.<span style=3D'mso-spacerun:yes'>&nbsp; </span><o:p></=
o:p></span></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal style=3D'text-align:justify;mso-pagination:widow-orpha=
n;
tab-stops:-1.0in -.5in 0in'><span style=3D'font-size:11.0pt;mso-bidi-font-s=
ize:
10.0pt;font-family:Arial;mso-bidi-font-family:"Times New Roman"'><o:p>&nbsp=
;</o:p></span></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal style=3D'text-align:justify;mso-pagination:widow-orpha=
n;
tab-stops:-1.0in -.5in 0in'><span style=3D'font-size:11.0pt;mso-bidi-font-s=
ize:
10.0pt;font-family:Arial;mso-bidi-font-family:"Times New Roman"'>Despite
physical and geographic barriers, <st1:City w:st=3D"on"><st1:place w:st=3D"=
on">Northfield</st1:place></st1:City>
also participates in several regional organizations to address such issues =
of
local concern as solid waste management, transportation and transit service,
and a variety of social service and economic development functions.<span
style=3D'mso-spacerun:yes'>&nbsp; </span>Nothing in this plan anticipates s=
caling
back participation in any of these regional organizations or severing exist=
ing
inter-municipal arrangements with neighboring towns. <o:p></o:p></span></p>

<span style=3D'font-size:11.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:10.0pt;font-family:Arial;
mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman";mso-bidi-font-family:"Times New R=
oman";
mso-ansi-language:EN-US;mso-fareast-language:EN-US;mso-bidi-language:AR-SA;
layout-grid-mode:line'><br clear=3Dall style=3D'page-break-before:always'>
</span>

<p class=3DMsoNormal style=3D'text-align:justify;mso-pagination:widow-orpha=
n;
tab-stops:-1.0in -.5in 0in'><span style=3D'font-size:11.0pt;mso-bidi-font-s=
ize:
10.0pt;font-family:Arial;mso-bidi-font-family:"Times New Roman"'>Compatibil=
ity
with neighboring towns is particularly important with regard to land use, w=
here
incompatible policies could result in conflicting development activities and
land uses along town boundaries.<span style=3D'mso-spacerun:yes'>&nbsp;
</span>Northfield&#8217;s land use plan calls for agriculture, forestry, lo=
w to
moderate density residential development and very limited non-residential u=
ses
along the boundaries with Roxbury, Waitsfield, Moretown, Williamston and mo=
st
of Berlin.<span style=3D'mso-spacerun:yes'>&nbsp; </span>A portion of the s=
hared
boundary with <st1:State w:st=3D"on">Berlin</st1:State> &#8211; adjacent to
historic <st1:place w:st=3D"on"><st1:PlaceName w:st=3D"on">Northfield</st1:=
PlaceName>
 <st1:PlaceType w:st=3D"on">Falls</st1:PlaceType></st1:place> &#8211; allow=
s a
greater mix of uses and higher densities befitting the traditional settleme=
nt
pattern of this historic growth center.<span style=3D'mso-spacerun:yes'>&nb=
sp;
</span>These uses and densities are not incompatible with those allowed in
adjacent towns which have adopted zoning, although both Williamstown and
Roxbury have not implemented their respective land use plans through
development regulations.<span style=3D'mso-spacerun:yes'>&nbsp; </span><o:p=
></o:p></span></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal style=3D'text-align:justify;mso-pagination:widow-orpha=
n;
tab-stops:-1.0in -.5in 0in'><span style=3D'font-size:11.0pt;mso-bidi-font-s=
ize:
10.0pt;font-family:Arial;mso-bidi-font-family:"Times New Roman"'><o:p>&nbsp=
;</o:p></span></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal style=3D'text-align:justify;mso-pagination:widow-orpha=
n;
tab-stops:-1.0in -.5in 0in'><span style=3D'font-size:11.0pt;mso-bidi-font-s=
ize:
10.0pt;font-family:Arial;mso-bidi-font-family:"Times New Roman"'>In additio=
n to
land use, a brief review of neighboring municipal plans does not reveal any
notable incompatibility of plan goals or policies.<span
style=3D'mso-spacerun:yes'>&nbsp; </span>Likewise, no areas of incompatibil=
ity
between this plan and the Central Vermont Regional Plan have been
identified.<span style=3D'mso-spacerun:yes'>&nbsp; </span>Thus, it is the
position of <st1:City w:st=3D"on"><st1:place w:st=3D"on">Northfield</st1:pl=
ace></st1:City>
that this plan is compatible with all of the adopted plans of neighboring
communities and the region. <o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal style=3D'text-align:justify;mso-pagination:widow-orpha=

n;

ze:
11.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:10.0pt;font-family:Arial;mso-bidi-font-family:"Ti=
mes New Roman"'>In
some respects, the preparation of this plan was a direct outgrowth of the
Northfield Community Visit conducted by the Vermont Council on Rural
Development in association with several state and regional agencies.<span
style=3D'mso-spacerun:yes'>&nbsp; </span>This visit involved a series of
community meetings held between November 2001 and January 2002 that involved
dozens of community residents and municipal officials.<span
style=3D'mso-spacerun:yes'>&nbsp; </span>The key community priorities outli=
ned
over the course of that process were carried forward into this document.<sp=
an
style=3D'mso-spacerun:yes'>&nbsp; </span>An overview of the community visit=
 is
available in a Final Report dated January 2002.<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=3DMsoHeader style=3D'text-align:justify;mso-pagination:widow-orpha=
n;
tab-stops:-1.0in -.5in 0in center 3.0in right 6.0in'><span style=3D'font-si=

mes New Roman"'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></span></p>

<p class=3DMsoHeader style=3D'text-align:justify;mso-pagination:widow-orpha=
n;
tab-stops:-1.0in -.5in 0in center 3.0in right 6.0in'><span style=3D'font-si=
ze:

mes New Roman"'>In
addition, the Planning Commission circulated early draft chapters of this
document to a variety of interest groups and potential stakeholders to soli=
cit
comments on specific issues of likely interest.<span
style=3D'mso-spacerun:yes'>&nbsp; </span>Three public informational meeting=
s were
also held to address housing concerns and community and economic development
strategies. <o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=3DMsoHeader style=3D'text-align:justify;mso-pagination:widow-orpha=

<p class=3DMsoHeader style=3D'text-align:justify;mso-pagination:widow-orpha=

mes New Roman"'>The
plan also benefited from a variety of issue-specific planning and developme=
nt
projects that have been undertaken by the community in recent years (e.g.,
Downtown Study, Gray Building Feasibility Study).<span
style=3D'mso-spacerun:yes'>&nbsp; </span>Those efforts are cited in appropr=
iate
locations of the draft. <o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=3DMsoHeader style=3D'text-align:justify;line-height:110%;mso-pagin=

<p class=3DMsoHeader style=3D'text-align:justify;line-height:110%;mso-pagin=

widow-orphan;tab-stops:-1.0in -.5in 0in center 3.0in right 6.0in'><span

amily:
Arial;mso-bidi-font-family:"Times New Roman"'>Finally, through a Vermont
Municipal Planning Grant secured by the Planning Commission, the Commission
hired the services of Burnt Rock Inc., Associates in Community Planning, of
Waitsfield who assisted with all aspects of the plan update.<o:p></o:p></sp=
an></p>

<span style=3D'font-size:11.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:10.0pt;line-height:110%;

amily:
"Times New Roman";mso-ansi-language:EN-US;mso-fareast-language:EN-US;
mso-bidi-language:AR-SA;layout-grid-mode:line'><br clear=3Dall style=3D'mso=
-special-character:
line-break;page-break-before:always'>
</span>

<p class=3DMsoHeader style=3D'text-align:justify;line-height:110%;mso-pagin=
ation:
widow-orphan;tab-stops:-1.0in -.5in 0in center 3.0in right 6.0in'><span
style=3D'font-size:11.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:10.0pt;line-height:110%;font-f=
amily:
Arial;mso-bidi-font-family:"Times New Roman"'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></span></p>

<div style=3D'mso-element:para-border-div;border:solid windowtext 1.0pt;
mso-border-alt:solid windowtext .5pt;padding:1.0pt 4.0pt 1.0pt 4.0pt;
background:black'>

<p class=3DMsoNormal align=3Dcenter style=3D'text-align:center;background:b=
lack;
border:none;mso-border-alt:solid windowtext .5pt;padding:0in;mso-padding-al=
t:
1.0pt 4.0pt 1.0pt 4.0pt'><b style=3D'mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'><span
style=3D'font-size:14.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:10.0pt;font-family:Wingdings;
mso-ascii-font-family:Arial;mso-hansi-font-family:Arial;color:white;mso-cha=
r-type:
symbol;mso-symbol-font-family:Wingdings'><span style=3D'mso-char-type:symbo=
l;
mso-symbol-font-family:Wingdings'>&#353;</span></span></b><b style=3D'mso-b=
idi-font-weight:
normal'><span style=3D'font-size:14.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:10.0pt;font-fami=
ly:
Arial;mso-bidi-font-family:"Times New Roman";color:white'><span
style=3D'mso-spacerun:yes'>&nbsp; </span><span style=3D'text-transform:uppe=
rcase'>A
Brief History of <st1:City w:st=3D"on"><st1:place w:st=3D"on">Northfield</s=
t1:place></st1:City><span
style=3D'mso-spacerun:yes'>&nbsp; </span></span></span></b><b style=3D'mso-=
bidi-font-weight:
normal'><span style=3D'font-size:14.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:10.0pt;font-fami=
ly:
Wingdings;mso-ascii-font-family:Arial;mso-hansi-font-family:Arial;color:whi=
te;
mso-char-type:symbol;mso-symbol-font-family:Wingdings'><span style=3D'mso-c=
har-type:
symbol;mso-symbol-font-family:Wingdings'>&#8250;</span></span></b><b
style=3D'mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'><span style=3D'font-size:14.0pt;mso-b=
idi-font-size:
10.0pt;font-family:Arial;mso-bidi-font-family:"Times New Roman";color:white=
'><o:p></o:p></span></b></p>

</div>

<p class=3DMsoNormal style=3D'text-align:justify'><b style=3D'mso-bidi-font=
-weight:
normal'><span style=3D'font-size:11.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:10.0pt;font-fami=
ly:
Arial;mso-bidi-font-family:"Times New Roman";text-transform:uppercase'><o:p=
>&nbsp;</o:p></span></b></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal style=3D'margin-bottom:3.0pt;text-align:justify'><span
style=3D'font-size:11.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:10.0pt;font-family:Arial;mso-b=
idi-font-family:
"Times New Roman"'>From 1785 through the 1820s, largely Yankees from <st1:S=
tate
w:st=3D"on">Connecticut</st1:State>, <st1:State w:st=3D"on">Massachusetts</=
st1:State>,
and the older <st1:State w:st=3D"on">Vermont</st1:State> towns settled <st1=
:City
w:st=3D"on"><st1:place w:st=3D"on">Northfield</st1:place></st1:City>.<span
style=3D'mso-spacerun:yes'>&nbsp; </span>Next to arrive were the Irish, att=
racted
in the 1840&#8217;s by jobs on the railroad.<span
style=3D'mso-spacerun:yes'>&nbsp; </span>The Welsh arrived after the Irish =
to
work in the slate quarries in the 1850&#8217;s and 1860&#8217;s.<span
style=3D'mso-spacerun:yes'>&nbsp; </span>Stonework also brought the next
wave.<span style=3D'mso-spacerun:yes'>&nbsp; </span>Starting about 1890,
Italians, Spaniards, and Scots joined the workforce in the granite sheds.<s=
pan
style=3D'mso-spacerun:yes'>&nbsp; </span>From the 1880&#8217;s onward, Cana=
dians
of French descent came seeking opportunity, many buying up hill farms aband=
oned
in the decades after the Civil War.<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal style=3D'margin-bottom:3.0pt;text-align:justify'><span
style=3D'font-size:11.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:10.0pt;font-family:Arial;mso-b=
idi-font-family:
"Times New Roman"'>The years from 1785 to 1825 saw the development of <st1:=
City
w:st=3D"on"><st1:place w:st=3D"on">Northfield</st1:place></st1:City>&#8217;=
s four
villages.<span style=3D'mso-spacerun:yes'>&nbsp; </span>The first settlemen=
t was
on East Hill (now Mill Hill), close by Elijah Paine&#8217;s grist and
sawmills.<span style=3D'mso-spacerun:yes'>&nbsp; </span>As the population g=
rew,
boundaries crept up the hill and northward along Route 12.<span
style=3D'mso-spacerun:yes'>&nbsp; </span>Clusters of houses became villages=
, each
with its own personality and name:<span style=3D'mso-spacerun:yes'>&nbsp; <=
/span><st1:PlaceName
w:st=3D"on">South</st1:PlaceName> <st1:PlaceType w:st=3D"on">Village</st1:P=
laceType>,
<st1:PlaceType w:st=3D"on">Center</st1:PlaceType> <st1:PlaceType w:st=3D"on=
">Village</st1:PlaceType>,
<st1:place w:st=3D"on"><st1:PlaceName w:st=3D"on">Factory</st1:PlaceName> <=
st1:PlaceType
 w:st=3D"on">Village</st1:PlaceType></st1:place>, and the Falls.<o:p></o:p>=
</span></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal style=3D'margin-bottom:3.0pt;text-align:justify'><span
style=3D'font-size:11.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:10.0pt;font-family:Arial;mso-b=
idi-font-family:
"Times New Roman"'>First to have a distinct identity was <st1:place w:st=3D=
"on"><st1:PlaceName
 w:st=3D"on"><b style=3D'mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>South</b></st1:PlaceN=
ame><b
 style=3D'mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'> <st1:PlaceType w:st=3D"on">Village<=
/st1:PlaceType></b></st1:place>,
which had numerous small businesses and manufacturing operations through the
nineteenth century.<span style=3D'mso-spacerun:yes'>&nbsp; </span>Next was =
<b
style=3D'mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>Center Village</b>, where the first p=
ost
office, town clerk&#8217;s office, and churches were established, and which=
 for
many years was the social and political center of town.<span
style=3D'mso-spacerun:yes'>&nbsp; </span>After the Center came Factory Vill=
age
(the present Village of Northfield) named for the woolen mill located
there.<span style=3D'mso-spacerun:yes'>&nbsp; </span>Last to develop was <b
style=3D'mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>Northfield Falls</b>, and by the late
1820&#8217;s it, too, was a thriving community.<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal style=3D'margin-bottom:3.0pt;text-align:justify'><span
style=3D'font-size:11.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:10.0pt;font-family:Arial;mso-b=
idi-font-family:
"Times New Roman"'>With the arrival of the railroad in the 1840&#8217;s,
Factory Village and Depot Square increasingly became the hub of local
activity.<span style=3D'mso-spacerun:yes'>&nbsp; </span>Residents there beg=
an to
demand lighted streets, sidewalks, fire and police protection, and they then
petitioned the legislature to establish a separate Village of Northfield.<s=
pan
style=3D'mso-spacerun:yes'>&nbsp; </span>The Village of Northfield was inco=
rporated
November 14, 1855.<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal style=3D'margin-bottom:3.0pt;text-align:justify'><span
style=3D'font-size:11.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:10.0pt;font-family:Arial;mso-b=
idi-font-family:
"Times New Roman"'>Over the next fifty years, village residents voted taxes=
 on
themselves for a variety of services.<span style=3D'mso-spacerun:yes'>&nbsp;
</span>Sidewalks were laid down, the w<b style=3D'mso-bidi-font-weight:norm=
al'>ater
department</b> was established and the first <b style=3D'mso-bidi-font-weig=
ht:
normal'>electric plant</b> was built (both in 1895), and the first sewer li=
nes
were laid (1901-1904).<span style=3D'mso-spacerun:yes'>&nbsp; </span>Around=
 1900 the
<b style=3D'mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>police department</b> was set up, =
and
the two independent <b style=3D'mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>fire companies=
,</b>
which existed from the 1860&#8217;s, came under village control.<o:p></o:p>=
</span></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal style=3D'margin-bottom:3.0pt;text-align:justify'><span
style=3D'font-size:11.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:10.0pt;font-family:Arial;mso-b=
idi-font-family:
"Times New Roman"'>The price of such amenities was high; consequently, as t=
hey
were increasingly needed outside the village, police, and fire services were
taken over by the town.<span style=3D'mso-spacerun:yes'>&nbsp; </span>The t=
own
and village <b style=3D'mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>highway departments</b=
> were
supported by taxes levied separately on the grand lists of the village and
town.<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal style=3D'margin-bottom:3.0pt;text-align:justify'><span
style=3D'font-size:11.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:10.0pt;font-family:Arial;mso-b=
idi-font-family:
"Times New Roman"'>Once settlements were established, people turned their
attention to making a living.<span style=3D'mso-spacerun:yes'>&nbsp; </span=
>Of necessity,
almost everyone was a farmer first, and most lived by barter (goods and
services were paid for with other goods and services).<span
style=3D'mso-spacerun:yes'>&nbsp; </span>Eventually people needed hard cash=
, and
it was this quest for individual and collective economic security that has =
been
the paramount concern in Northfield for two centuries.<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal style=3D'margin-bottom:3.0pt;text-align:justify'><span
style=3D'font-size:11.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:10.0pt;font-family:Arial;mso-b=
idi-font-family:
"Times New Roman"'>Until about 1814, residents made potash on their farms a=
nd
sent it to mills in America and abroad which used it for everything from
finishing wool cloth to making glass.<span style=3D'mso-spacerun:yes'>&nbsp;
</span>About 1812, as the demand for potash was waning, Elijah Paine built a
huge woolen mill on the site of the now closed Cetrangolo Finishing works
(which closed in 1999).<span style=3D'mso-spacerun:yes'>&nbsp;
</span>Paine&#8217;s woolen mill employed between 175 and 200 workers and w=
as
for years the town&#8217;s largest employer.<span
style=3D'mso-spacerun:yes'>&nbsp; </span><o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal style=3D'margin-bottom:3.0pt;text-align:justify'><span
style=3D'font-size:11.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:10.0pt;font-family:Arial;mso-b=
idi-font-family:
"Times New Roman"'>When wool prices declined in the 1840&#8217;s, Elijah
Paine&#8217;s son Charles came to the rescue.<span
style=3D'mso-spacerun:yes'>&nbsp; </span>As President of the Vermont Central
Railroad, Charles Paine pushed the line from Windsor, Vermont to Burlington,
finishing construction on the last day of 1849, and locating the
railroad&#8217;s headquarters in Northfield.<span
style=3D'mso-spacerun:yes'>&nbsp; </span>For fifteen years the Vermont Cent=
ral
Railroad meant prestige for Northfield and prosperity for its citizens &#82=
11;
hundreds worked for the line.<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<span style=3D'font-size:11.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:10.0pt;font-family:Arial;
mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman";mso-bidi-font-family:"Times New R=
oman";
mso-ansi-language:EN-US;mso-fareast-language:EN-US;mso-bidi-language:AR-SA;
layout-grid-mode:line'><br clear=3Dall style=3D'page-break-before:always'>
</span>

<p class=3DMsoNormal style=3D'margin-bottom:3.0pt;text-align:justify'><span
style=3D'font-size:11.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:10.0pt;font-family:Arial;mso-b=
idi-font-family:
"Times New Roman"'>In 1852, Paine lost control of his railroad.<span
style=3D'mso-spacerun:yes'>&nbsp; </span>Over the next decade the new owners
gradually moved operations to St. Albans.<span style=3D'mso-spacerun:yes'>&=
nbsp;
</span>John Gregory Smith, the new president, said he would &#8220;make the
grass grow in the streets of Northfield.&#8221;<span
style=3D'mso-spacerun:yes'>&nbsp; </span>He very nearly succeeded.<span
style=3D'mso-spacerun:yes'>&nbsp; </span>The town&#8217;s population, one o=
f the
largest in Vermont at the time, dropped precipitously and over fifty houses
stood vacant.<span style=3D'mso-spacerun:yes'>&nbsp; </span>It took 25 year=
s to
recover from the loss.<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal style=3D'margin-bottom:3.0pt;text-align:justify'><span
style=3D'font-size:11.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:10.0pt;font-family:Arial;mso-b=
idi-font-family:
"Times New Roman"'>Slate quarrying and finishing, which started early in the
nineteenth century, provided some respite.<span style=3D'mso-spacerun:yes'>=
&nbsp;
</span>In the 1860&#8217;s and 1870&#8217;s some two hundred men worked for=
 the
slate companies, but by the 1880&#8217;s this industry too was in decline.<=
span
style=3D'mso-spacerun:yes'>&nbsp; </span><o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal style=3D'margin-bottom:3.0pt;text-align:justify'><span
style=3D'font-size:11.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:10.0pt;font-family:Arial;mso-b=
idi-font-family:
"Times New Roman"'>The next savior was granite.<span
style=3D'mso-spacerun:yes'>&nbsp; </span>In 1889 investors built a spur lin=
e and
a small finishing shed on railroad land and arranged to have granite brought
down from the Barre quarries.<span style=3D'mso-spacerun:yes'>&nbsp; </span=
>Several
more sheds were eventually constructed, and by the outbreak of World War I,
over 525 people were employed in the sheds.<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal style=3D'margin-bottom:3.0pt;text-align:justify'><span
style=3D'font-size:11.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:10.0pt;font-family:Arial;mso-b=
idi-font-family:
"Times New Roman"'>Times changed, and by 1954 only the Rock of Ages plant w=
as
left, and that too was closed when the head office decided it was too expen=
sive
to ship the rough stone here.<span style=3D'mso-spacerun:yes'>&nbsp; </span=
>In
1999 Cetrangolo Finishing Works, founded in 1955, was the last to close.<sp=
an
style=3D'mso-spacerun:yes'>&nbsp; </span>As of August 2000, the Cetrangolo
Finishing Works building has been demolished and the site is vacant.<o:p></=
o:p></span></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal style=3D'margin-bottom:3.0pt;text-align:justify'><span
style=3D'font-size:11.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:10.0pt;font-family:Arial;mso-b=
idi-font-family:
"Times New Roman"'>In the end, economic rejuvenation came from what at first
might have seemed an unpromising source.<span style=3D'mso-spacerun:yes'>&n=
bsp;
</span>Late in 1886, the faculty and student body of Norwich University arr=
ived
in town.<span style=3D'mso-spacerun:yes'>&nbsp; </span>Their arrival follow=
ed
acceptance by Norwich trustees of a bid by a group of citizens to have the
college relocated here.<span style=3D'mso-spacerun:yes'>&nbsp; </span>It is
doubtful that anyone seeing the four teachers and fourteen students arrive
imagined that the college would become the town&#8217;s largest employer.<o=
:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal style=3D'margin-bottom:3.0pt;text-align:justify'><span
style=3D'font-size:11.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:10.0pt;font-family:Arial;mso-b=
idi-font-family:
"Times New Roman"'>Beside the large industries, small-scale manufacturing
operations and retail businesses of many kinds flourished here in the
nineteenth and early twentieth centuries.<span style=3D'mso-spacerun:yes'>&=
nbsp;
</span>This diversity was common in Vermont, and Northfield was no
exception.<span style=3D'mso-spacerun:yes'>&nbsp; </span>Collectively these=
 stores
and manufacturers gave employment to many, and economic health to the commu=
nity
for decades.<span style=3D'mso-spacerun:yes'>&nbsp; </span><o:p></o:p></spa=
n></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal style=3D'margin-bottom:3.0pt;text-align:justify'><span
style=3D'font-size:11.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:10.0pt;font-family:Arial;mso-b=
idi-font-family:
"Times New Roman"'>The Great Depression hastened the end of many
businesses.<span style=3D'mso-spacerun:yes'>&nbsp; </span>Henry Ford and his
competitors made the demise of other businesses certain.<span
style=3D'mso-spacerun:yes'>&nbsp; </span>Mass production of the automobile =
and a
revived national economy after 1945 put Vermonters on wheels and took them =
out
of town to work and shop.<span style=3D'mso-spacerun:yes'>&nbsp; </span>The
importance of the automobile as a bringer of change cannot be overstated.<s=
pan
style=3D'mso-spacerun:yes'>&nbsp; </span>In Northfield, as elsewhere, it me=
ant
workers no longer had to depend on local businesses for jobs and shopping
opportunities; they could drive anywhere employment was available and goods
were for sale.<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal style=3D'margin-bottom:3.0pt;text-align:justify'><span
style=3D'font-size:11.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:10.0pt;font-family:Arial;mso-b=
idi-font-family:
"Times New Roman"'>As manufacturing jobs declined, the importance of Norwich
University increased.<span style=3D'mso-spacerun:yes'>&nbsp; </span>About 1=
950,
Norwich, Rock of Ages, and the Nantanna textile mill each employed
approximately 140 people.<span style=3D'mso-spacerun:yes'>&nbsp; </span>By =
1963,
Rock of Ages went out of business.<span style=3D'mso-spacerun:yes'>&nbsp;
</span>Though the college has seen ups and downs over the past 125 years, i=
ts
presence has been an economic force for the community and a social and cult=
ural
life Northfield probably would not otherwise have seen.<o:p></o:p></span></=
p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal style=3D'text-align:justify'><span style=3D'font-size:=
11.0pt;
mso-bidi-font-size:10.0pt;font-family:Arial;mso-bidi-font-family:"Times New=
 Roman"'>Since
World War II, population growth has been slow but steady.<span
style=3D'mso-spacerun:yes'>&nbsp; </span>The town has seen none of the
large-scale tourism that has brought mixed blessings to other Vermont
towns.<span style=3D'mso-spacerun:yes'>&nbsp; </span>While no large industr=
y has
come to town, a number of small businesses have sprung up.<span
style=3D'mso-spacerun:yes'>&nbsp; </span>Slightly more than half of the
Northfield labor force worked out of town.<span style=3D'mso-spacerun:yes'>=
&nbsp;
</span>Over two centuries, Northfield evolved from farming to manufacturing=
 to
a mix of small businesses and a college town economy.<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal style=3D'text-align:justify'><b style=3D'mso-bidi-font=
-weight:
normal'><span style=3D'font-size:11.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:10.0pt;font-fami=
ly:
Arial;mso-bidi-font-family:"Times New Roman"'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></span></b><=
/p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal style=3D'text-align:justify'><b style=3D'mso-bidi-font=
-weight:
normal'><span style=3D'font-size:11.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:10.0pt;font-fami=
ly:
Arial;mso-bidi-font-family:"Times New Roman"'>[Northfield Historical Societ=
y]</span></b><span
style=3D'font-size:11.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:10.0pt;font-family:Arial;mso-b=
idi-font-family:
"Times New Roman"'><o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal style=3D'text-align:justify'><u><span style=3D'font-si=
ze:11.0pt;
mso-bidi-font-size:10.0pt;font-family:Arial;mso-bidi-font-family:"Times New=
 Roman"'><o:p><span
 style=3D'text-decoration:none'>&nbsp;</span></o:p></span></u></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal style=3D'margin-bottom:3.0pt;text-align:justify'><u><s=
pan
style=3D'font-size:11.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:10.0pt;font-family:Arial;mso-b=
idi-font-family:
"Times New Roman"'>References</span></u><span style=3D'font-size:11.0pt;
mso-bidi-font-size:10.0pt;font-family:Arial;mso-bidi-font-family:"Times New=
 Roman"'>:<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal style=3D'margin-bottom:3.0pt;text-align:justify'><span
style=3D'font-size:11.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:10.0pt;font-family:Arial;mso-b=
idi-font-family:
"Times New Roman"'>McIntire, Julia. (1981 Fall).<span
style=3D'mso-spacerun:yes'>&nbsp; </span><u>History of Northfield</u>.<span
style=3D'mso-spacerun:yes'>&nbsp; </span>Central Vermont Views, 3, No. 1, 2=
8-33.<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal style=3D'margin-bottom:3.0pt;text-align:justify'><span
style=3D'font-size:11.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:10.0pt;font-family:Arial;mso-b=
idi-font-family:
"Times New Roman"'>McIntire, J. W., and Cleveland, R.L. (1985). Picture
Northfield: A Photographic Study.<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal style=3D'text-align:justify'><span style=3D'font-size:=
11.0pt;
mso-bidi-font-size:10.0pt;font-family:Arial;mso-bidi-font-family:"Times New=
 Roman"'>The
Northfield Town Committee (1974). <u>Green Mountain Heritage: The Chronicle=
 of
Northfield, Vermont</u>.<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<span style=3D'font-size:11.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:10.0pt;font-family:Arial;
mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman";mso-bidi-font-family:"Times New R=
oman";
mso-ansi-language:EN-US;mso-fareast-language:EN-US;mso-bidi-language:AR-SA;
layout-grid-mode:line'><br clear=3Dall style=3D'page-break-before:always'>
</span>

<p class=3DMsoNormal align=3Dcenter style=3D'text-align:center'><b style=3D=
'mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'><span style=3D'font-size:16.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:10.0pt;font-fami=
ly:
Arial;mso-bidi-font-family:"Times New Roman";text-transform:uppercase'>Chap=
ter
2.<span style=3D'mso-spacerun:yes'>&nbsp; </span>Natural &amp; Cultural Res=
ources<o:p></o:p></span></b></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal style=3D'text-align:justify'><b style=3D'mso-bidi-font=
-weight:
normal'><span style=3D'font-size:11.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:10.0pt;font-fami=
ly:
Arial;mso-bidi-font-family:"Times New Roman"'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></span></b><=
/p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal style=3D'text-align:justify'><b style=3D'mso-bidi-font=
-weight:
normal'><span style=3D'font-size:11.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:10.0pt;font-fami=
ly:
Arial;mso-bidi-font-family:"Times New Roman"'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></span></b><=
/p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal style=3D'text-align:justify'><b style=3D'mso-bidi-font=
-weight:
normal'><i style=3D'mso-bidi-font-style:normal'><span style=3D'font-size:14=
.0pt;
mso-bidi-font-size:10.0pt;font-family:Arial;mso-bidi-font-family:"Times New=
 Roman"'>2.1<span
style=3D'mso-tab-count:1'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; </span>Overview<o:p></o:=
p></span></i></b></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal style=3D'text-align:justify'><span style=3D'font-size:=
11.0pt;
mso-bidi-font-size:10.0pt;font-family:Arial;mso-bidi-font-family:"Times New=
 Roman"'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></span></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal style=3D'text-align:justify'><span style=3D'font-size:=
11.0pt;
mso-bidi-font-size:10.0pt;font-family:Arial;mso-bidi-font-family:"Times New=
 Roman"'>Northfield&#8217;s
physical character and identity, its unique &#8220;sense of place,&#8221; is
defined by both its natural setting and its built environment.<span
style=3D'mso-spacerun:yes'>&nbsp; </span>Local topography and natural featu=
res
helped shape historic patterns of development, which in turn offer a framew=
ork
for future growth.<span style=3D'mso-spacerun:yes'>&nbsp; </span>Many of
Northfield&#8217;s most significant natural and historic features remain
remarkably intact, and contribute much to the attractiveness of the communi=
ty
and to the overall quality of life in town.<span
style=3D'mso-spacerun:yes'>&nbsp; </span><o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal style=3D'text-align:justify'><span style=3D'font-size:=
11.0pt;
mso-bidi-font-size:10.0pt;font-family:Arial;mso-bidi-font-family:"Times New=
 Roman"'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></span></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal style=3D'text-align:justify'><span style=3D'font-size:=
11.0pt;
mso-bidi-font-size:10.0pt;font-family:Arial;mso-bidi-font-family:"Times New=
 Roman"'>Northfield
does not have to go the way of many communities that are losing their sense=
 of
identity and place to nondescript, homogeneous forms of development.<span
style=3D'mso-spacerun:yes'>&nbsp; </span>Such development can adversely imp=
act
the natural environment, and is inconsistent with the historic character of=
 the
built environment.<span style=3D'mso-spacerun:yes'>&nbsp; </span>Giving due
consideration to the town&#8217;s natural and historic features, and the
potential impacts of development on these resources, is critical to protect
environmental quality and community identity, and to preserve that which ma=
kes
Northfield a special place to live, work and visit. <o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal style=3D'text-align:justify'><span style=3D'font-size:=
11.0pt;
mso-bidi-font-size:10.0pt;font-family:Arial;mso-bidi-font-family:"Times New=
 Roman"'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></span></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal style=3D'text-align:justify'><b style=3D'mso-bidi-font=
-weight:
normal'><i style=3D'mso-bidi-font-style:normal'><span style=3D'font-size:14=
.0pt;
mso-bidi-font-size:10.0pt;font-family:Arial;mso-bidi-font-family:"Times New=
 Roman"'>2.2<span
style=3D'mso-tab-count:1'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; </span>Topography &amp;
Drainage<o:p></o:p></span></i></b></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal style=3D'text-align:justify'><span style=3D'font-size:=
11.0pt;
mso-bidi-font-size:10.0pt;font-family:Arial;mso-bidi-font-family:"Times New=
 Roman"'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></span></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal style=3D'text-align:justify'><span style=3D'font-size:=
11.0pt;
mso-bidi-font-size:10.0pt;font-family:Arial;mso-bidi-font-family:"Times New=
 Roman"'>Northfield
lies in the heart of the Dog River valley, defined by the Northfield Range =
to
the west, and the Irish Hill ridge, including Paine Mountain, to the east.<=
span
style=3D'mso-spacerun:yes'>&nbsp; </span>The Dog River, fed locally by a nu=
mber
of tributaries within the local drainage area, flows northward into the
Winooski, west of Montpelier, and eventually into Lake Champlain.<span
style=3D'mso-spacerun:yes'>&nbsp; </span>Elevations in town range from arou=
nd 650
feet where the Dog River crosses into Berlin, to over 2500 ft along the
town&#8217;s western border in the Northfield Range.<span
style=3D'mso-spacerun:yes'>&nbsp; </span>Prominent peaks to the east include
Paine Mountain (2411 ft.), Turkey Hill (1888 ft.), and Shaw Mountain (1820 =
ft.).<span
style=3D'mso-spacerun:yes'>&nbsp; </span>Around 62 acres of land are located
above 2,500 feet &#8211; all in the Northfield Range &#8211; and are subjec=
t to
Act 250 review if developed. <o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal style=3D'text-align:justify'><span style=3D'font-size:=
11.0pt;
mso-bidi-font-size:10.0pt;font-family:Arial;mso-bidi-font-family:"Times New=
 Roman"'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></span></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal style=3D'text-align:justify'><span style=3D'font-size:=
11.0pt;
mso-bidi-font-size:10.0pt;font-family:Arial;mso-bidi-font-family:"Times New=
 Roman"'>River
valleys provided natural transportation routes for prehistoric populations,=
 and
early settlers.<span style=3D'mso-spacerun:yes'>&nbsp; </span>The &#8220;Pa=
ine Turnpike&#8221;
(now called Berlin Pond Road) connecting Brookfield and Montpelier, was fir=
st
constructed up the Dog River valley in 1799, opening up the town to settlem=
ent
and trade with the outside world.<span style=3D'mso-spacerun:yes'>&nbsp;
</span>The Vermont Central Railroad, completed through the valley in 1847,
established Northfield Village as an important regional commercial and
industrial center.<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal style=3D'text-align:justify'><span style=3D'font-size:=
11.0pt;
mso-bidi-font-size:10.0pt;font-family:Arial;mso-bidi-font-family:"Times New=
 Roman"'><span
style=3D'mso-spacerun:yes'>&nbsp;</span><o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal style=3D'text-align:justify'><span style=3D'font-size:=
11.0pt;
mso-bidi-font-size:10.0pt;font-family:Arial;mso-bidi-font-family:"Times New=
 Roman"'>Historically,
settlement was concentrated in the narrow confines of the valley floor in
locations where the power of the Dog River and its tributaries could be eas=
ily
harnessed.<span style=3D'mso-spacerun:yes'>&nbsp; </span>Northfield&#8217;s=
 four
historic villages &#8211; South Village, Center Village, Factory (Northfiel=
d)
Village, and Northfield Falls &#8211; all developed first as mill sites.<sp=
an
style=3D'mso-spacerun:yes'>&nbsp; </span>Some of these areas lie within the=
 flood
plain of the Dog River and as such have been subject to periodic flooding o=
ver
the years.<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal style=3D'text-align:justify'><span style=3D'font-size:=
11.0pt;
mso-bidi-font-size:10.0pt;font-family:Arial;mso-bidi-font-family:"Times New=
 Roman"'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></span></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal style=3D'text-align:justify'><span style=3D'font-size:=
11.0pt;
mso-bidi-font-size:10.0pt;font-family:Arial;mso-bidi-font-family:"Times New=
 Roman"'>As
farms extended into the surrounding hills, much of the forests were cleared=
 for
agriculture and potash production &#8211; the town&#8217;s earliest
industry.<span style=3D'mso-spacerun:yes'>&nbsp; </span>Upland areas suppor=
ted
subsistence farming, and for a time commercial sheep and dairy farms.<span
style=3D'mso-spacerun:yes'>&nbsp; </span>The clearing of steeper slopes, ho=
wever,
also resulted in accelerated stormwater runoff and soil erosion, which depl=
eted
local soils.<span style=3D'mso-spacerun:yes'>&nbsp; </span><o:p></o:p></spa=
n></p>

<span style=3D'font-size:11.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:10.0pt;font-family:Arial;
mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman";mso-bidi-font-family:"Times New R=
oman";
mso-ansi-language:EN-US;mso-fareast-language:EN-US;mso-bidi-language:AR-SA;
layout-grid-mode:line'><br clear=3Dall style=3D'page-break-before:always'>
</span>

<p class=3DMsoNormal style=3D'text-align:justify'><span style=3D'font-size:=
11.0pt;
mso-bidi-font-size:10.0pt;font-family:Arial;mso-bidi-font-family:"Times New=
 Roman"'>With
the abandonment of the hill farms over the last century, most of the
town&#8217;s uplands have reverted to forests.<span
style=3D'mso-spacerun:yes'>&nbsp; </span>These areas now support logging
operations and wildlife populations, and provide a highly visible and scenic
backdrop to the valley below.<span style=3D'mso-spacerun:yes'>&nbsp; </span=
>They
are also increasingly attractive for low-density residential development, a=
nd
high elevation uses such as telecommunications towers and wind generation
facilities.<span style=3D'mso-spacerun:yes'>&nbsp; </span>If poorly sited a=
nd
developed, such uses can adversely impact upland headwater and groundwater
recharge areas, timber stands, critical wildlife habitat, and scenic views.=
<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal style=3D'text-align:justify'><!--[if gte vml 1]><v:sha=
petype

    Development Suitability <o:p></o:p></span></b></p>
    <p class=3DMsoNormal><span style=3D'font-size:10.0pt;font-family:Arial;
    mso-bidi-font-family:"Times New Roman"'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></span></p>

pan

    mso-bidi-font-family:"Times New Roman"'>Slope</span></u><span

    mso-bidi-font-family:"Times New Roman"'><span style=3D'mso-tab-count:1'=
>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; </span><u>Recommended
    Management<o:p></o:p></u></span></p>
    <p class=3DMsoNormal style=3D'margin-left:.5in;text-indent:-.5in'><span
    style=3D'font-size:9.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:10.0pt;font-family:Arial;
    mso-bidi-font-family:"Times New Roman"'><span style=3D'mso-tab-count:1'=
>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&n=
bsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; </span><o:p></o:p></span></p>
    <p class=3DMsoNormal style=3D'margin-left:.5in;text-indent:-.5in'><span
    style=3D'font-size:9.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:10.0pt;font-family:Arial;
    mso-bidi-font-family:"Times New Roman"'>0-3%<span style=3D'mso-tab-coun=
t:
    1'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; </span>Suitable for development, may
    require drainage improvements<o:p></o:p></span></p>
    <p class=3DMsoNormal style=3D'margin-left:.5in;text-indent:-.5in'><span
    style=3D'font-size:9.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:10.0pt;font-family:Arial;
    mso-bidi-font-family:"Times New Roman"'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></span></p>
    <p class=3DMsoNormal style=3D'margin-left:.5in;text-indent:-.5in'><span
    style=3D'font-size:9.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:10.0pt;font-family:Arial;
    mso-bidi-font-family:"Times New Roman"'>3-8%<span style=3D'mso-tab-coun=
t:
    1'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; </span>Most desirable for development,
    having the least restrictions<o:p></o:p></span></p>
    <p class=3DMsoNormal style=3D'margin-left:.5in;text-indent:-.5in'><span
    style=3D'font-size:9.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:10.0pt;font-family:Arial;
    mso-bidi-font-family:"Times New Roman"'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></span></p>
    <p class=3DMsoNormal style=3D'margin-left:.5in;text-indent:-.5in'><span
    style=3D'font-size:9.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:10.0pt;font-family:Arial;
    mso-bidi-font-family:"Times New Roman"'>8-15%<span style=3D'mso-tab-cou=
nt:
    1'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; </span>Suitable for low-density development with
    consideration given to erosion control, runoff, and septic design<o:p><=
/o:p></span></p>
    <p class=3DMsoNormal style=3D'margin-left:.5in;text-indent:-.5in'><span
    style=3D'font-size:9.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:10.0pt;font-family:Arial;
    mso-bidi-font-family:"Times New Roman"'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></span></p>
    <p class=3DMsoNormal style=3D'margin-left:.5in;text-indent:-.5in'><span
    style=3D'font-size:9.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:10.0pt;font-family:Arial;
    mso-bidi-font-family:"Times New Roman"'>15-25%<span style=3D'mso-tab-co=
unt:
    1'>&nbsp; </span>Unsuitable for most development and septic systems; ru=
noff
    and erosion problems likely; any construction should be carefully manag=
ed<o:p></o:p></span></p>
    <p class=3DMsoNormal style=3D'margin-left:.5in;text-indent:-.5in'><span
    style=3D'font-size:9.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:10.0pt;font-family:Arial;
    mso-bidi-font-family:"Times New Roman"'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></span></p>
    <p class=3DMsoNormal style=3D'margin-left:.5in;text-indent:-.5in'><span
    style=3D'font-size:9.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:10.0pt;font-family:Arial;
    mso-bidi-font-family:"Times New Roman"'>25%+<span style=3D'mso-tab-coun=
t:
    1'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; </span>All construction should be avoided;
    careful land management is required</span><span style=3D'font-size:10.0=
pt;
    font-family:Arial;mso-bidi-font-family:"Times New Roman"'>.<o:p></o:p><=
/span></p>
    <p class=3DMsoNormal style=3D'margin-left:56.1pt;text-indent:-56.1pt'><=
span
    style=3D'font-size:10.0pt;font-family:Arial;mso-bidi-font-family:"Times=
 New Roman"'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></span></p>
    <p class=3DMsoNormal style=3D'margin-left:56.1pt;text-indent:-56.1pt'><=
